General Alvear has appointed Brgadiel

The army of the Republic has fallen bacl

Cooper's"Spy of the Neutral Ground" or tie
true Hurrey Birch.-This gentleman, far gone
| in years, whose real name is F. c., re-
sides in the town ofC--, in the State of New
York, about twelve miles from the "Fishklll

rian Church Of c. Society Mr.. Cooper
has given US an accurate description of his per-

discover any emotion of his mind lie seldom
feels disposed to speak of his hair.breadth es-
capes and severe privations, while engaged III
the service of his country, during the Revolu-
tionary struggle: But whenever he enters up
on this story, it is with modesty and self abase-
nent that he was criminal as to act the part
Of ''litlshai the hrchte," in the presence OF the
servants of George the Sd. The writer of this

these GLOW great has been the mercy ot God
TO me, that was not cut off in the midst Of my
career Of deceit and wickednes,! have acted
too much from the principle mentionpd by the
/ Apostle Paul. 'let us 10 evil that good may come


In the year 1775, Gf remember right, he
was employed as i spy by the friciids OF Aneri-
can Liberty. He then lived in the county Of
Wcstchestcr, little south Of the chain OF noun
tains called ''tlie Highlands" During this year
he travelled to Canada anil back again, for the
purpose of learning the sentiments OF the peo-
pie concerning the;~ar, and OF asccv;aimng who
were the most active and dangerous mcr among
the tories. To this class OF men, he protested
great friendship for the British ministry, anGs ex-
pressed fears that he should become a prisoner
to the wings, who would deprive him ot NJ, =
The information obtained by the spy, ocra.Aon-
ed the arrest and imprisonment OF several roya,.
lists.


In the wear i1-, he was frequently in New-
York, in company with the principal officers Of
the British army, who placed in linn the utrln,t
confidence. From this time to the cwl ct The
war, he was considered as a spy for thc rnSasts,
and the principal thcatr, Of his operations waa
! in the country contiguous - New York and the
"Ilighhnds.' Under different DISCUSSES and
assumed names, such as John Smith, Harvey
/ Wright, and IIar cy Birch, he travelled throussl
many towns, obtaining important information
which he communicated to the American gem
erals. His employment necessarily subjected
him to perils. Sometimes he MAS shot At by
the friends Of liberty, who were eagrc to d-stroy
one engaged Gas they thousht) in the service OF
< their enemies. Several times lie "1s their prls.
oncr, but his ingenuity effected his escape,


Several companies Of tories, oiiicered with
men from the British army, fell into thr hlm!s
oi the Americans, III consequence of his aGralt
ness. 1t was customary With the British officers
TO steal their way into the country, and obt.n
recruits from among the torres, which were
marched to Tie Support Of the lrirlsh army
The Spy enlisted several tunes n,ider snch o't
\ Gers aud when hc had asccrtained the .mc fix
ei upon for marching 70 unite With the myrmi
dons Of King Gcorgr, lic never failed Of secret


" appr4ng soTac principal officer Of the Amer


can amy, who, oi cour,r, was not tardy in 1t


frcting thcw surrender at discretion In sucl


instances, the Spy became prisoner, hut t.r,or
ed by friends, who knew his real character, h


always to0k French leave of absence"

.ino,Aey.--Some months since certain
adroit parsonage obtained his discharge un-
der the insolvent act in the course OF winch
process he assigned according to law,
All his estate, real and personal. including
the debts due him, to one of his friends
Within three months afterwards the same
friend had also occasion to apply for the ben
eft of the insoyent act. and by way Of re-
wardng good turn. made an assignment
of his effect to the first insolvent, so they
were assignees to each other. The parties
then interchanged powers of attorney, and
each insolvent was thus enabled TO Collect
the debts due himself before his failure.
which they did very promptly, leaving their
creditors in the mean time, to enjoy the
pleasure of anticipating dividend which
was not very likely to come to their hands.

A line of policy has been adopted throughout
many states of the Union, for the sencourage-
ment OF finternal Improvement and manufactures,
on the broadcst scale, calculated in its operation
to dcveope their resources and forward their in.
tcrcsts.


The central position Of Pennsylvania, her soil,
wealth, local apv ,ntages for establishing manu-
factories, and her immense mineral treasures OF
coal, iron, salt, &c. deposited at distance from
her navgabe rivers, point her out as member
of the un,on especially called upon to take the
lead in this great scheme of national improve
Inent.


A conviction of the truth of this position, and
Of the course She ought to pursue, has dawned
upon the public mind; md her citizens have
declred that the advantages bestowed upon her
| by nature, shall no longer remain unimpovedt
her policy now cmphatically declares that her
moral and physical energies and resources shall
be developed ard maturcd.


To promote this honorable and beneficial de.
sicn the Editor of the Miners journal published
at Mont Carbon, intends, if sufficient encourage
rnent be afforded, to enlarge his plan and to pub.
lish daily, and three times, and once week, at
the city of Phlladephla, paper under the tue
Of the PennSy'gaRla Gazette, devoted to Internal
Improvement, Elucrtion, Agriculture, Com
marce, and Manufactures.


The following is an outline Of the plan which
IS intended to BE pursued ilr the conduct OF tins
Journal.


Authentic notices of The design, situation, and
progress of all public works, canals, railways
road, manufactures, &c. OF this state.


All new and useful inventions and discoveries
Which may be useful to the merchant, farmer OF
manufacturer.


Commercial information ofall kinds.


Education, jurisprudence, with view OF INC
politics of PENNSYLVANIA and OF the Cnoh


The history, statistics, institutions, poleY,, e.
vents and improvements OF the city OF fhiiaueF
phia and other portions oi the state will be par
ticnlarly attended to.


Early and original reports of the proceednSS
of legislature Of TIL State of Pennsylvania 10,
gether with 4 summary of the proceedings ol
Congress.


Interesting law and police cases.


Foreign and domestic events and occurrences
which may he generally useful and interesting.


Notices of works OF merit issuing from the
press, with extracts from the most popular pc
riodicaIs sha be freely given 10 cnliven the col
umns of the Gazette.


The whole shall be accompanied with sueh
editorial remarks and eXposltions as may "
deemed necessary and proper to promote 'ae
honor, prosperity and welfare OF this great s'a'e
and its metropolis.


The PENNSYLVANIA GAZETTE, win labour tr
promote all useful measures and improvements
and especially to point out and develope VIC
manifold resources of this state. Her moral
political, and physical advancement shall ever h'
ITS paramount care; and in discharge oi tt's u'-
~ the editor will use his cxcrtions 10 make tne
city better acquainted with the country, and t''S
country bcs.er acquainted with the cityi AM
conviction i, felt that in the place OF the ds'i'
; and sectional preiulices now existing, mH'"N'
good feeling respect and esteem, and inrch pNp
: lie benefit will be the result.
+. With SO many useful objects in view, i wo''.'

:, aid fcarle SLY canva SD Temporary ropula''

s m ,licious or misleading the unwary. Broad COZ.

n system of plain political common sense Le aa'' :

p0STDAM, June 26th, 1927.

An examination OF the pupils oftbe Choc
taw Academy at the Blue Springs, Kentuc.
Ky, will commence on the 18th of July
There are about one hundred Indian boys
at this Academy. from the tribes OF the
Choctaws. Greeks, and others A part Of

months, aud have made considerable pro
gress. The subject is an interesting one to
the friends OF religion and civil improve
mcnt.

narrowed, and made mellow for the seed.
Notwithstanding the well known saying,
that more corn grows in crooked rows than
in dtraight ones" his rows are planted as
straight as an arrow, so that in ploughin9
between them he is not obliged to tack eve
~ rod or two, like vessel sailing ~lth
head wind. And as he is particular IN the
preparation of the SOIL and planting the seed,
so he dOef not stand with his hands IN his
ppckets after planting. His hoes OF which
pc has the best kind, are bright, and as 1t
we're, polished with labor. Not a weed is
allowed to claim right to his fields by long
possession. In fact, he elects them Gas the
~tawyers say) by summary process. In the
time Of drought he does not keep turning
his eyes to the clouds with black and dis
NAL csunteDance and exclaming ''there will
be no corn this ear !" while his fields are
baking to death for want os ploughing and
hoeing. He is constantly on his feet, stir
ing tine ground, and keeping its bosom open
20 the dews and whatever moisture may be
gained from the atmosphere, or from the
earth beneath. And while the com OF his
neighbor Look is dropping its head and
rolling its blades with thirst, that of Willy
Snug ls green and ilourishing and finally
yields reasonable if not abundant harvest.
Willy Snug is well aware Of the effect of
moisture in producing plentiful crops. OF
course, Whenever the water can Ee turned
by raising a small dam and digging chan
mel, II Is done, aud the refreshing element
spread III gentle and almost invisible rllls
sver the surface of his meadows: which are
always TO be seen smiling and vcrlait, and
annually rcpayins the small expense OF cul-
sivatlon. Neither is the beauty Of nature
thrown away in haying time by bad manage
he IL in, ih,a
son for making the best hay and most OF il.
II is not tnown SO early rs to be what some
people cali wishy.washy, nor allowed to
stand so late as to loose all its sweet and
nourishing juice, and drop off its seed and
blades in handling, leaving nothing for the
poor horses and cattle but the bare, scar,
good nothing stalk. And when the
grass is cut, the boys are amongst it with
Sheir rakes and pitch-forks, and keeping 1t
moving as long as the sun shines, and until
it is properly cared and fitted for the NOV,
where it may be seen the next spring a.
bright and sweet as when first slowed away
Willy Snug is equally careful in the preser-
walton of his grain and usually gets SIX
pence more for every bushel he sells than
his neighbors, by reason of his iudicloua man
agement. As for hay. he AYERS that he can
rarely afford to sell it, for with every load
OF hay, he is obliged to part With load OF
more of manure, and thus far is impovcrish-
ing his farm.


In regard to building and fences, Willy
Snug is emphatlcally what his name implies
Every thing is snug about them. His build
lnss are never to be seen, ike these Of hi
neighbor Look on, glazed with old hats, ant
painted by the hand Of time and weather.
On the contrary, every window has i's du,
proportion Of glass, and every inch of wood
work its appropriate covering of oil ant
paint. The stone walls are well built anc
in good condition; not panel, or any paM
of one, is wanting in his ram tel,ces; and tht
posts instead Of standing every way, like :
company OF militia, are set i'll so straight
line that you might take sight over the top
OF a hundred OF them as we'll az on the bar
rel of rife There are no briars, o bush
-s, no thistles, no tall unsightly weeds grow
ing beside the fences, but all rs smotle, nti
and productive as the rest of the enclosure


John Wesley used to say that farmer
were the most discontented race of being
in the world; that they were never satistie
either with God or man. If this acc omit b
true, Willy Snug Is certainly an excepticl
He takes the seasons as they come, dischar
ges his own duty, and leaves the rest I
Heaven. He is not always complaining ,
tiS weather., as OtlnS LOO not OF LOO Cuit
TOO wet or too dry, and taking occasion fror
this dissatisfaction to neglect his business
He has no horribly dull days, no time
which he cannot work. He is not seen Of
rainy afternoon lettering At the tavern {
going away two or three miles with fsl
pole on his shoulder. He always fnt
something to do at home. An axe is to t
ground, a rake to be mended, seeds to |
prepared for planting, and thousand 9th,
things to be attended to, which can be do,
without exposure to the rain. And whe
these matters are discharged, there is anotl
er, which Willy Snug is careful not to ne


lect, viz reading the newspaper. In fac
he affirms it to be an infallible remedy f
the blues" and worth all the whiskey, ru
and brandy in neigh5or Signpost's bar.


The same industry, the same good ma
agement, and the same cheerful humor a
tend upon Willy Snug throughout the ye;
He doe: not throw away in winter the ha
earned and precious products of his SUI


ner's labor. His time is spent i'll feedi


and taking care of his stock, laying il


years supply of wood, and, during the 10


winter evening, in improving his own mi


BY reading. and improving the minds OF


children. No sleigh-rides, no drunk,


bouts no killing of horses, no dancing


night to crafty a vile taste for frolck


and fashionable amusement Neverthele


Willy Snug is no niggard There is no


more bountifal table than his in the pari
and brings back in return number Of bush

whole Of the battalion deserted. itteEscd =

PROPOSALS

Nature and Natures God smile upon the IN.
ion that is sweetened by love and sanct6ed NV
law. The sphere of our affection is enlarged
and our pleasures take wider range. We be.
come more important and respected among men
and existence itself is doubly enjoyed with this
our softer self Misfortune loses halfits anguish
beneath the soothing influence of her smiles, and
triumph becomes more triumphant when shared
with her. Without her what is mani Arovinp
aud restless being; driven at pleasure by roman.
tic speculation, anl cheated into misery by fu.
tile hopes-the mad victim ofuntamed passions.
and the disappointed pursuer Of fiuitless ioys--
But with her he awakens to new life. lie fol.
lows a path--wider and noblcr than the narrow
road 10 self aggranIisement--this is scattered
with more fragrant flowers, and illumined by q
clearer light.

full articles.headline: BANDA ORIENTAL.
full articles.article:
A letter from CanelonCs states, that oil tho Pth
inst the lralans made a sally out of Monte
Vidco, 10 the number Of 1900 men, and marched
towards pando. In consequence of this, the
provincial government, seated III Canelones, fear
ing visit from these gentry, left the town, to-
gcther with the archevcs and officers, and pass
Ell the night in a wood little distance off. On
the day following, they learned that the Brazil
ans had retired at O'Clock the preceding even
ing. The letter gives very unt;,vorable ac-
count us the state Of the Patriot lines without
the city, us the troops on actual service do not
exceed 100 men, which are inadequate to form
a respectable corps Of observation. Particular
/ hopes are entertained Of General Soler's being
able To return with several hundred men, wei
mount cd and armed.


General Alvear has appointed Brgadiel
Soler 20 the military command Of the Banda
Oriental, with all the plenitude of powers
! which his Excelenoy the President has con
fcrred on him.


The army of the Republic has fallen bacl
to the Tacurembo, tor the purpose Of re
cruiting its cavalry. 1t has upwards O
10000 excellent horses in possession.


We are informed, that SO apprehe naiy
are the Imperiaists OF Monte Video, of a
uufriendly visit from Admiral Brown, tn
guns in the batteries are kept double shot
ted, and the artillery men arc made t
sleep near them.

full articles.headline: From the Boston Telegraph.
full articles.article:
The following communication is fian the
Rev. A. b. q Presbyterian clergyman OF this
county.


Cooper's"Spy of the Neutral Ground" or tie
true Hurrey Birch.-This gentleman, far gone
| in years, whose real name is F. c., re-
sides in the town ofC--, in the State of New
York, about twelve miles from the "Fishklll
Highlands" He is worthy man, possessed OF
a fine farm, and for many Years has sustained TIC
office of Deacon in the Congregational Presbyte-
rian Church Of c. Society Mr.. Cooper
has given US an accurate description of his per-
son which is tall and meagre, and indicative OF
great muscular strength. Reserved in his man
ners and maintaining an nvarabe rlgldity OF
features one would find it extremely difficult to
discover any emotion of his mind lie seldom
feels disposed to speak of his hair.breadth es-
capes and severe privations, while engaged III
the service of his country, during the Revolu-
tionary struggle: But whenever he enters up
on this story, it is with modesty and self abase-
nent that he was criminal as to act the part
Of ''litlshai the hrchte," in the presence OF the
servants of George the Sd. The writer of this
article has heard him utter such expressions AS
these GLOW great has been the mercy ot God
TO me, that was not cut off in the midst Of my
career Of deceit and wickednes,! have acted
too much from the principle mentionpd by the
/ Apostle Paul. 'let us 10 evil that good may come


In the year 1775, Gf remember right, he
was employed as i spy by the friciids OF Aneri-
can Liberty. He then lived in the county Of
Wcstchestcr, little south Of the chain OF noun
tains called ''tlie Highlands" During this year
he travelled to Canada anil back again, for the
purpose of learning the sentiments OF the peo-
pie concerning the;~ar, and OF asccv;aimng who
were the most active and dangerous mcr among
the tories. To this class OF men, he protested
great friendship for the British ministry, anGs ex-
pressed fears that he should become a prisoner
to the wings, who would deprive him ot NJ, =
The information obtained by the spy, ocra.Aon-
ed the arrest and imprisonment OF several roya,.
lists.


In the wear i1-, he was frequently in New-
York, in company with the principal officers Of
the British army, who placed in linn the utrln,t
confidence. From this time to the cwl ct The
war, he was considered as a spy for thc rnSasts,
and the principal thcatr, Of his operations waa
! in the country contiguous - New York and the
"Ilighhnds.' Under different DISCUSSES and
assumed names, such as John Smith, Harvey
/ Wright, and IIar cy Birch, he travelled throussl
many towns, obtaining important information
which he communicated to the American gem
erals. His employment necessarily subjected
him to perils. Sometimes he MAS shot At by
the friends Of liberty, who were eagrc to d-stroy
one engaged Gas they thousht) in the service OF
< their enemies. Several times lie "1s their prls.
oncr, but his ingenuity effected his escape,


Several companies Of tories, oiiicered with
men from the British army, fell into thr hlm!s
oi the Americans, III consequence of his aGralt
ness. 1t was customary With the British officers
TO steal their way into the country, and obt.n
recruits from among the torres, which were
marched to Tie Support Of the lrirlsh army
The Spy enlisted several tunes n,ider snch o't
\ Gers aud when hc had asccrtained the .mc fix
ei upon for marching 70 unite With the myrmi
dons Of King Gcorgr, lic never failed Of secret


" appr4ng soTac principal officer Of the Amer


can amy, who, oi cour,r, was not tardy in 1t


frcting thcw surrender at discretion In sucl


instances, the Spy became prisoner, hut t.r,or
ed by friends, who knew his real character, h


always to0k French leave of absence"

wards, hayitg p4.d the costs G sFuit,es'
.ino,Aey.--Some months since certain
adroit parsonage obtained his discharge un-
der the insolvent act in the course OF winch
process he assigned according to law,
All his estate, real and personal. including
the debts due him, to one of his friends
Within three months afterwards the same
friend had also occasion to apply for the ben
eft of the insoyent act. and by way Of re-
wardng good turn. made an assignment
of his effect to the first insolvent, so they
were assignees to each other. The parties
then interchanged powers of attorney, and
each insolvent was thus enabled TO Collect
the debts due himself before his failure.
which they did very promptly, leaving their
creditors in the mean time, to enjoy the
pleasure of anticipating dividend which
was not very likely to come to their hands.

full articles.article:
From Btenos tyres, papers Of 22th and Slst


March, rcce, cd at the ET.lntagt9aiaa ONce.


The provinces oft the interior present most
heaIt-rcndng spectacle. At a moment when
the legations Of the republic march triumphant
in the territory oi tho sworn enemy Of Argentine
liberty and Independence 10 avcnge its wrongs,
when the national ilag waves victorious in the
waters Of La Plata, aud OIL the coast of the hos
tile empire, when union ana energy are only nc
ccssatyto give the death blow to tll. y rant, vino


in the m,oNication OF his pride, conceived the
bold project Of red, ing ficemcn 10 the bond
OF scryltntc; the fratricide arms Of civil dissen-
ton are brandishngin in the heart Of the nation,
and threaten to make il tIlc scene Of all the hor.
rors Of anarchy and dcsola,ion, and ,he sal mon.
umcnt Of the bancfA effects Of party spirit.
when its object is to turthcr'the ends Of lndivid-
/ ual ambition.


C0rdora.-The Chcfof this province, B2&tng,


appears to be the leader OF the anarchists The


motive he alIedgcs for the line of conduct lie
I pursucs is that the Constituent Congress has Vi


olated the fundamental laws Of the Union, but it


is too evident that he is act,iated by ambition -


Whilst he pretends 70 defend the province a.
! gainst the illegal enchroachmcnts OF the Nation.


al Authorities, he himself is curtailins their lib


critics in the mnst scandlluus manncr. Tie or.
denances of police he has published would dis
grace hlgcrs II is true thlt he has a great ma


ny partizans, but they are chiefly composed o
fanatics and declared enemies Of social order. =


We do not mean by this, To cast any Iciiectiul


on the character Of the inhabitants Of Cordova


we are aware that the greater part Of them si!a
for the redemption Of their province from it,
present degradation.


SaRa.--After having male noble stand fo
,he cause of order, thi, province has fallen pre-,
4 to the anarchists. The national forces CON
, manded by Col. Bcdoya, were not long SING
i completely routed bv tho under the cnnman,
: Of Col Gorriti, who had been oncl by 200 yel
: eran Colombian troops who had deserted fro1
Il Bolivia. As soon as Gen. Arcnales, Governor q
{, the Province learnt the news Of the defeat of
. forces, he fed, and Col. Gorriti entering in II
" umph into the city, was elected to iii that olfiC,
:. He, however, shortly resigned, and Col Gurt
:, was cho en- in his stead.


y MeHdozd.-The recent resolve Of the Lcgisl
70 t'ire Of this province not to examine the const
, tuition, at present, gives reason to doubt of u


ia, orable disposition Of its Authorities towar,
Is the National Government 1t is said that Il
- step taken by the Mcndozian Chamber Of Re
n resentatiycs Was influenced by the following ei
Us cunstanccs When the Emperor Of Brazil le
ne Rio Janero TO take the command Of the imperi
army in Rio Grande, the President of the X
an public, addressed proclamation to the Provi
vn ces calling upon them to furnish all the aid thu
he could, to repel the enemy, as it was believed
or would attempt to invade the capital Mendo
of was the only province that licarkened to the d
= mand. The Government Immediately order,
az battalion of grenadiers to set out for this ci,
- ~ which had proceeded but e few days marc
- when the National Government, having lcai
y the intelligence of the invasion of San Juan
"a QuIRooA, sent an express TO Mendoza orderi
ID the battalion to remain there to watch Qurog
Is movements. The Authorities Of Mendo
IS thinking that by SO doing they would incur
IT dspleasure of this Chief, ordered it to contin


its march. Its commander sgnificd his init


ton of obeying the order of President, and t
to Government of Mendoza resolved to oppose
x. return During these alterations, nearly I

full articles.headline: The Pennsy\vania Gazette,
full articles.article:
.4.r;cul,urc, Commerce and Manufactures.


A line of policy has been adopted throughout
many states of the Union, for the sencourage-
ment OF finternal Improvement and manufactures,
on the broadcst scale, calculated in its operation
to dcveope their resources and forward their in.
tcrcsts.


The central position Of Pennsylvania, her soil,
wealth, local apv ,ntages for establishing manu-
factories, and her immense mineral treasures OF
coal, iron, salt, &c. deposited at distance from
her navgabe rivers, point her out as member
of the un,on especially called upon to take the
lead in this great scheme of national improve
Inent.


A conviction of the truth of this position, and
Of the course She ought to pursue, has dawned
upon the public mind; md her citizens have
declred that the advantages bestowed upon her
| by nature, shall no longer remain unimpovedt
her policy now cmphatically declares that her
moral and physical energies and resources shall
be developed ard maturcd.


To promote this honorable and beneficial de.
sicn the Editor of the Miners journal published
at Mont Carbon, intends, if sufficient encourage
rnent be afforded, to enlarge his plan and to pub.
lish daily, and three times, and once week, at
the city of Phlladephla, paper under the tue
Of the PennSy'gaRla Gazette, devoted to Internal
Improvement, Elucrtion, Agriculture, Com
marce, and Manufactures.


The following is an outline Of the plan which
IS intended to BE pursued ilr the conduct OF tins
Journal.


Authentic notices of The design, situation, and
progress of all public works, canals, railways
road, manufactures, &c. OF this state.


All new and useful inventions and discoveries
Which may be useful to the merchant, farmer OF
manufacturer.


Commercial information ofall kinds.


Education, jurisprudence, with view OF INC
politics of PENNSYLVANIA and OF the Cnoh


The history, statistics, institutions, poleY,, e.
vents and improvements OF the city OF fhiiaueF
phia and other portions oi the state will be par
ticnlarly attended to.


Early and original reports of the proceednSS
of legislature Of TIL State of Pennsylvania 10,
gether with 4 summary of the proceedings ol
Congress.


Interesting law and police cases.


Foreign and domestic events and occurrences
which may he generally useful and interesting.


Notices of works OF merit issuing from the
press, with extracts from the most popular pc
riodicaIs sha be freely given 10 cnliven the col
umns of the Gazette.


The whole shall be accompanied with sueh
editorial remarks and eXposltions as may "
deemed necessary and proper to promote 'ae
honor, prosperity and welfare OF this great s'a'e
and its metropolis.


The PENNSYLVANIA GAZETTE, win labour tr
promote all useful measures and improvements
and especially to point out and develope VIC
manifold resources of this state. Her moral
political, and physical advancement shall ever h'
ITS paramount care; and in discharge oi tt's u'-
~ the editor will use his cxcrtions 10 make tne
city better acquainted with the country, and t''S
country bcs.er acquainted with the cityi AM
conviction i, felt that in the place OF the ds'i'
; and sectional preiulices now existing, mH'"N'
good feeling respect and esteem, and inrch pNp
: lie benefit will be the result.
+. With SO many useful objects in view, i wo''.'
i be necessary to say, il 10 not intended 70 r"-
r ter into the endless cavils and snuositns OF poe
4 litical discussion !,
e Whenever the public good may demand y.
$ public men and public measures shall b, tresf
:, aid fcarle SLY canva SD Temporary ropula''
i'y viii not be sou ,ht afler by gratifying tl,e
s m ,licious or misleading the unwary. Broad COZ.
i stitaticnal principles shall be espoused' ana
n system of plain political common sense Le aa'' :
IS Gated and enforced,


IS Reporters " II be employed to attend the SIS,
sions of our legislature and all public Inec0"sJI
within rtaiom,e distance of p 'adelphIF' a,'s.
II measures have been taken TO obtia tue carr.
C information OF all that is passing Throughout Ia
h country In ha
10 In short, neither labor nor expense WIN ~
spared, nc- aag source Of Information i's ""'N

time since, was discharged under the insolv-
ent act. A few days afterwards an officer

.1noiher.-An insolvent some time since

home in dashing carriage, to the surprise
and doubtless the infinite admiration oi the
creditors, who .yalkcd home shortly after

full articles.headline:
From Correspondent ofMe " y Courier.


p0STDAM, June 26th, 1927.
full articles.article:
Gentlenen;--Wc have "signs Of the times" at
the North as well as the South. A few days
since at the annual Catholic Celebration at St.
Regis, the British flag was carried into the
church by the British indians, when the Ameri-
can indians carried in, or attempted to, the A.
mercan Aag, which caused general fight
The result was the death Of one American and
one British Indian, and one Frenchman, by stab
bing 1t may not be generally known that
there are ,wo parties of Indians at st. Regis, one
full blooded Yankees, the other John BuiI's
former supporters Tic church Is on the Can
ada side where most ol both parties live. II Is
said that tie American flag viii be hoisted at oI
rear Min Roche. few miles above Cornwall, or
the 4th Of Jus! so, think sc may anticipate
general row.

An examination OF the pupils oftbe Choc
taw Academy at the Blue Springs, Kentuc.
Ky, will commence on the 18th of July
There are about one hundred Indian boys
at this Academy. from the tribes OF the
Choctaws. Greeks, and others A part Of
them have attended more than twelve
months, aud have made considerable pro
gress. The subject is an interesting one to
the friends OF religion and civil improve
mcnt.

full articles.headline: and brings back in return number Of bush
full articles.article:
narrowed, and made mellow for the seed.
Notwithstanding the well known saying,
that more corn grows in crooked rows than
in dtraight ones" his rows are planted as
straight as an arrow, so that in ploughin9
between them he is not obliged to tack eve
~ rod or two, like vessel sailing ~lth
head wind. And as he is particular IN the
preparation of the SOIL and planting the seed,
so he dOef not stand with his hands IN his
ppckets after planting. His hoes OF which
pc has the best kind, are bright, and as 1t
we're, polished with labor. Not a weed is
allowed to claim right to his fields by long
possession. In fact, he elects them Gas the
~tawyers say) by summary process. In the
time Of drought he does not keep turning
his eyes to the clouds with black and dis
NAL csunteDance and exclaming ''there will
be no corn this ear !" while his fields are
baking to death for want os ploughing and
hoeing. He is constantly on his feet, stir
ing tine ground, and keeping its bosom open
20 the dews and whatever moisture may be
gained from the atmosphere, or from the
earth beneath. And while the com OF his
neighbor Look is dropping its head and
rolling its blades with thirst, that of Willy
Snug ls green and ilourishing and finally
yields reasonable if not abundant harvest.
Willy Snug is well aware Of the effect of
moisture in producing plentiful crops. OF
course, Whenever the water can Ee turned
by raising a small dam and digging chan
mel, II Is done, aud the refreshing element
spread III gentle and almost invisible rllls
sver the surface of his meadows: which are
always TO be seen smiling and vcrlait, and
annually rcpayins the small expense OF cul-
sivatlon. Neither is the beauty Of nature
thrown away in haying time by bad manage
he IL in, ih,a
son for making the best hay and most OF il.
II is not tnown SO early rs to be what some
people cali wishy.washy, nor allowed to
stand so late as to loose all its sweet and
nourishing juice, and drop off its seed and
blades in handling, leaving nothing for the
poor horses and cattle but the bare, scar,
good nothing stalk. And when the
grass is cut, the boys are amongst it with
Sheir rakes and pitch-forks, and keeping 1t
moving as long as the sun shines, and until
it is properly cared and fitted for the NOV,
where it may be seen the next spring a.
bright and sweet as when first slowed away
Willy Snug is equally careful in the preser-
walton of his grain and usually gets SIX
pence more for every bushel he sells than
his neighbors, by reason of his iudicloua man
agement. As for hay. he AYERS that he can
rarely afford to sell it, for with every load
OF hay, he is obliged to part With load OF
more of manure, and thus far is impovcrish-
ing his farm.


In regard to building and fences, Willy
Snug is emphatlcally what his name implies
Every thing is snug about them. His build
lnss are never to be seen, ike these Of hi
neighbor Look on, glazed with old hats, ant
painted by the hand Of time and weather.
On the contrary, every window has i's du,
proportion Of glass, and every inch of wood
work its appropriate covering of oil ant
paint. The stone walls are well built anc
in good condition; not panel, or any paM
of one, is wanting in his ram tel,ces; and tht
posts instead Of standing every way, like :
company OF militia, are set i'll so straight
line that you might take sight over the top
OF a hundred OF them as we'll az on the bar
rel of rife There are no briars, o bush
-s, no thistles, no tall unsightly weeds grow
ing beside the fences, but all rs smotle, nti
and productive as the rest of the enclosure


John Wesley used to say that farmer
were the most discontented race of being
in the world; that they were never satistie
either with God or man. If this acc omit b
true, Willy Snug Is certainly an excepticl
He takes the seasons as they come, dischar
ges his own duty, and leaves the rest I
Heaven. He is not always complaining ,
tiS weather., as OtlnS LOO not OF LOO Cuit
TOO wet or too dry, and taking occasion fror
this dissatisfaction to neglect his business
He has no horribly dull days, no time
which he cannot work. He is not seen Of
rainy afternoon lettering At the tavern {
going away two or three miles with fsl
pole on his shoulder. He always fnt
something to do at home. An axe is to t

For cnlargins THE MINERs' JOURNAL. and


converting it into Daily Paper, to be
published in PHILADELPHIA, and entitled

Nature and Natures God smile upon the IN.
ion that is sweetened by love and sanct6ed NV
law. The sphere of our affection is enlarged
and our pleasures take wider range. We be.
come more important and respected among men
and existence itself is doubly enjoyed with this
our softer self Misfortune loses halfits anguish
beneath the soothing influence of her smiles, and
triumph becomes more triumphant when shared
with her. Without her what is mani Arovinp
aud restless being; driven at pleasure by roman.
tic speculation, anl cheated into misery by fu.
tile hopes-the mad victim ofuntamed passions.
and the disappointed pursuer Of fiuitless ioys--
But with her he awakens to new life. lie fol.
lows a path--wider and noblcr than the narrow
road 10 self aggranIisement--this is scattered
with more fragrant flowers, and illumined by q
clearer light.
